element.name: Alarm
element.short: Schedule an alarm signal to be delivered

descr.p: Alarm schedules an alarm signal to be delivered to your process in Sec seconds. When Sec seconds have elapsed, Linux will send a SIGALRM signal to the current process. If Sec is zero, then no new alarm will be set. Whatever the value of Sec, any previous alarm is cancelled.
The function returns the number of seconds till the previously scheduled alarm was due to be delivered, or zero if there was none.

element.name: AssignPipe
element.short: Create a set of pipe file handlers

descr.p: AssignePipe creates a pipe, i.e. two file objects, one for input, one for output. What is written to Pipe_out, can be read from Pipe_in.
This call is overloaded. The in and out pipe can take three forms: an typed or untyped file, a text file or a file descriptor.
If a text file is passed then reading and writing from/to the pipe can be done through the usual Readln(Pipe_in,...) and Writeln(Pipe_out,...) procedures.
The function returns True if everything went succesfully, False otherwise.

errors.p: In case the function fails and returns False, LinuxError is used to report errors:

dl.dd: Too many file descriptors for this process.
The system file table is full.

element.name: AssignStream
element.short: Assign stream for in and output to a program

descr.p: AssignStream creates a 2 or 3 pipes, i.e. two (or three) file objects, one for input, one for output,(and one for standard error) the other ends of these pipes are connected to standard input and output (and standard error) of Prog. Prog is the name of a program (including path) with options, which will be executed.

What is written to StreamOut, will go to the standard input of Prog. Whatever is written by Prog to it's standard output can be read from StreamIn. Whatever is written by Prog to it's standard error read from StreamErr, if present.
Reading and writing happens through the usual Readln(StreamIn,...) and Writeln (StreamOut,...) procedures.
descr.remark: You should not use Reset or Rewrite on a file opened with POpen. This will close the file before re-opening it again, thereby closing the connection with the program.

descr.p: Clone creates a child process which is a copy of the parent process, just like does. In difference with Fork, however, the child process shares some parts of it's execution context with its parent, so it is suitable for the implementation of threads: many instances of a program that share the same memory.

When the child process is created, it starts executing the function Func, and passes it Args. The return value of Func is either the explicit return value of the function, or the exit code of the child process.
The sp pointer points to the memory reserved as stack space for the child process. This address should be the top of the memory block to be used as stack.

The Flags determine the behaviour of the Clone call. The low byte of the Flags contains the number of the signal that will be sent to the parent when the child dies. This may be bitwise OR'ed with the following constants:

dl.dd: Parent and child share the same memory space, including memory (un)mapped with subsequent mmap calls.
Parent and child have the same view of the filesystem; the chroot, chdir and umask calls affect both processes.
the file descriptor table of parent and child is shared.
the parent and child share the same table of signal handlers. The signal masks are different, though.
PArent and child have the same process ID.

descr.p: Clone returns the process ID in the parent process, and -1 if an error occurred.

errors.p: On error, -1 is returned to the parent, and no child is created.

dl.dd: Too many processes are running.
Not enough memory to create child process.

Due to the buffering mechanism of Pascal, this has not the same functionality as the dup call in C. The internal Pascal buffers are not the same after this call, but when the buffers are flushed (e.g. after output), the output is sent to the same file. Doing an lseek will, however, work as in C, i.e. doing a lseek will change the fileposition in both files.
The function returns False in case of an error, True if successful.

element.name: fdOpen
element.short: Open file and return file descriptor

descr.p: fdOpen opens a file in PathName with flags flags One of the following:

dl.dd: File is opened Read-only
File is opened Write-only
File is opened Read-Write

descr.p: The flags may beOR-ed with one of the following constants:

dl.dd: File is created if it doesn't exist.
If the file is opened with Open_Creat and it already exists, the call wil fail.
If the file is a terminal device, it will NOT become the process' controlling terminal.
If the file exists, it will be truncated.
the file is opened in append mode. Before each write, the file pointer is positioned at the end of the file.
The file is opened in non-blocking mode. No operation on the file descriptor will cause the calling process to wait till.
Idem as Open_NonBlock
The file is opened for synchronous IO. Any write operation on the file will not return untill the data is physically written to disk.
if the file is a symbolic link, the open fails. (linux 2.1.126 and higher only)
if the file is not a directory, the open fails. (linux 2.1.126 and higher only)

descr.p: PathName can be of type PChar or String. The optional mode argument specifies the permissions to set when opening the file. This is modified by the umask setting. The real permissions are Mode and not umask. The return value of the function is the filedescriptor, or a negative value if there was an error.

fdRead reads at most size bytes from the file descriptor fd, and stores them in buf. The function returns the number of bytes actually read, or -1 if an error occurred. No checking on the length of buf is done.
fdSeek sets the current fileposition of file fd to Pos, starting from SeekType, which can be one of the following:

dl.dd: Pos is the absolute position in the file.
Pos is relative to the current position.
Pos is relative to the end of the file.

descr.p: The function returns the new fileposition, or -1 of an error occurred.

descr.p: fdWrite writes at most size bytes from buf to file descriptor fd. The function returns the number of bytes actually written, or -1 if an error occurred.

descr.p: FRename renames the file OldName to NewName. NewName can be in a different directory than OldName, but it cannot be on another partition (device). Any existing file on the new location will be replaced.
If the operation fails, then the OldName file will be preserved.
The function returns True on succes, False on failure.

errors.p: On error, errors are reported in LinuxError. Possible errors include:

dl.dd: NewName exists and is a directory, but OldName is not a directory.
NewName and OldName are on different devices.
NewName is an existing, non-empty directory.
OldName or NewName is a directory and is in use by another process.
NewName is part of OldName.
OldPath or NewPath already have tha maximum amount of links pointing to them.
part of OldName or NewName is not directory.
For the pchar case: One of the pointers points to an invalid address.
access is denied when attempting to move the file.
Either OldName or NewName is too long.
a directory component in OldName or NewName didn't exist.
not enough kernel memory.
NewName or OldName is on a read-only file system.
too many symbolic links were encountered trying to expand OldName or NewName
the filesystem has no room for the new directory entry.

element.name: Kill
element.short: Send a signal to a process
element.descr: Send a signal Sig to a process or process group. If Pid>0 then the signal is sent to Pid, if it equals -1, then the signal is sent to all processes except process 1. If Pid<-1 then the signal is sent to process group -Pid. The return value is zero, except in case three, where the return value is the number of processes to which the signal was sent.

The Pid or process group don't exist.
The effective userid of the current process doesn't math the one of process Pid.

The filesystem containing oldpath and newpath doesn't support linking files.
Write access for the directory containing Newpath is disallowed, or one of the directories in OldPath or {NewPath} has no search (=execute) permission.
A directory entry in OldPath or NewPath does not exist or is a symbolic link pointing to a non-existent directory.
A directory entry in OldPath or NewPath is nor a directory.
Insufficient kernel memory.
The files are on a read-only filesystem.
NewPath already exists.
OldPath has reached maximal link count.
OldPath or NewPath has a reference to a circular symbolic link, i.e. a symbolic link, whose expansion points to itself.
The device containing NewPath has no room for another entry.
OldPath points to . or .. of a directory.

element.name: MMap
element.short: Create memory map of a file

descr.p: MMap maps or unmaps files or devices into memory. The different fields of the argument m determine what and how the mmap maps this:

dl.dd: Address where to mmap the device. This address is a hint, and may not be followed.
Size (in bytes) of area to be mapped.

dd.p: Protection of mapped memory. This is a OR-ed combination of the following constants:

dl.dd: The memory can be executed.
The memory can be read.
The memory can be written.
The memory can not be accessed.

dd.p: Contains some options for the mmap call. It is an OR-ed combination of the following constants:

dl.dd: Do not map at another address than the given address. If the address cannot be used, MMap will fail.
Share this map with other processes that map this object.
Create a private map with copy-on-write semantics.
fd does not have to be a file descriptor.

dd.p: One of the options MAP_SHARED and MAP_PRIVATE must be present, but not both at the same time.

dl.dd: File descriptor from which to map.
Offset to be used in file descriptor fd.

descr.p: The function returns a pointer to the mapped memory, or a -1 in case of en error.

errors.p: On error, -1 is returned and LinuxError is set to the error code:

dl.dd: fd is not a valid file descriptor and MAP_ANONYMOUS was not specified.
MAP_PRIVATE was specified, but fd is not open for reading. Or MAP_SHARED was asked and PROT_WRITE is set, fd is not open for writing
One of the record fields Start, length or offset is invalid.
MAP_DENYWRITE was set but the object specified by fd is open for writing.
fd is locked, or too much memory is locked.
Not enough memory for this operation.

element.name: NanoSleep
element.short: Suspend process for a short time

descr.p: NanoSleep suspends the process till a time period as specified in req has passed. Then the function returns. If the call was interrupted (e.g. by some signal) then the function may return earlier, and rem will contain the remaining time till the end of the intended period. In this case the return value will be -1, and LinuxError will be set to EINTR
If the function returns without error, the return value is zero.

element.errors: If the call was interrupted, -1 is returned, and LinuxError is set to EINTR. If invalid time values were specified, then -1 is returned and LinuxError is set to EINVAL.

descr.p: Nice adds -N to the priority of the running process. The lower the priority numerically, the less the process is favored. Only the superuser can specify a negative N, i.e. increase the rate at which the process is run.

element.descr: OpenDir opens the directory f, and returns a pdir pointer to a Dir record, which can be used to read the directory structure. If the directory cannot be opened, nil is returned.

element.name: POpen
element.short: Pipe file to standard input/output of program
element.descr: POpen runs the command specified in Cmd, and redirects the standard in or output of the command to the other end of the pipe F. The parameter rw indicates the direction of the pipe. If it is set to 'W', then F can be used to write data, which will then be read by the command from stdinput. If it is set to 'R', then the standard output of the command can be read from F. F should be reset or rewritten prior to using it. F can be of type Text or File. A file opened with POpen can be closed with Close, but also with . The result is the same, but PClose returns the exit status of the command Cmd.
element.errors: Errors are reported in LinuxError and are essentially those of the Execve, Dup and AssignPipe commands.

element.name: Select
element.short: Wait for events on file descriptors

descr.p: Select checks one of the file descriptors in the FDSets to see if its status changed.

readfds, writefds and exceptfds are pointers to arrays of 256 bits. If you want a file descriptor to be checked, you set the corresponding element in the array to 1. The other elements in the array must be set to zero. Three arrays are passed : The entries in readfds are checked to see if characters become available for reading. The entries in writefds are checked to see if it is OK to write to them, while entries in exceptfds are cheked to see if an exception occorred on them.
You can use the functions , or to manipulate the individual elements of a set.
The pointers can be Nil.
N is the largest index of a nonzero entry plus 1. (= the largest file-descriptor + 1).
TimeOut can be used to set a time limit. If TimeOut can be two types :

ol.li: TimeOut is of type PTime and contains a zero time, the call returns immediately. If TimeOut is Nil, the kernel will wait forever, or until a status changed.
TimeOut is of type Longint. If it is -1, this has the same effect as a Timeout of type PTime which is Nil. Otherwise, TimeOut contains a time in milliseconds.

descr.p: When the TimeOut is reached, or one of the file descriptors has changed, the Select call returns. On return, it will have modified the entries in the array which have actually changed, and it returns the number of entries that have been changed. If the timout was reached, and no decsriptor changed, zero is returned; The arrays of indexes are undefined after that. On error, -1 is returned.

errors.p: On error, the function returns -1, and Errors are reported in LinuxError :

dl.dd: An invalid descriptor was specified in one of the sets.
A non blocked signal was caught.
N is negative or too big.
Select was unable to allocate memory for its internal tables.

element.name: SelectText

element.descr: SelectText executes the call on a file of type Text. You can specify a timeout in TimeOut. The SelectText call determines itself whether it should check for read or write, depending on how the file was opened : With Reset it is checked for reading, with Rewrite and Append it is checked for writing.

element.descr: Shell invokes the bash shell (/bin/sh), and feeds it the command Command (using the -c option). The function then waits for the command to complete, and then returns the exit status of the command, or 127 if it could not complete the or calls.

Sa_Flags Speciefies a series of flags which modify the behaviour of the signal handler. You can 'or' none or more of the following :

descr.p: StringToPPChar splits the string S in words, replacing any whitespace with zero characters. It returns a pointer to an array of pchars that point to the first letters of the words in S. This array is terminated by a Nil pointer.
The function does not add a zero character to the end of the string unless it ends on whitespace.
The function reserves memory on the heap to store the array of PChar; The caller is responsible for freeing this memory.
This function can be called to create arguments for the various Exec calls.

element.name: SysCall
element.descr: SysCall can be used to execute a direct system call. The call parameters must be encoded in regs and the call number must be specified by callnr. The call result is returned, and any modified registers are in regs

element.name: tzdaylight
element.short: Indicates whether daylight savings time is active.

descr.p: SetTime sets the system time to hour, min, Sec. This is the kernel time, so it is in GMT. The date is not touched. The function returns True if the call was executed corretly, False otherwise.
descr.remark: You must be root to execute this call.

descr.p: SetDate sets the system date to year, month, day. This is the kernel date, so it is in GMT. The time is not touched. The function returns True if the call was executed corretly, False otherwise.
descr.remark: You must be root to execute this call.

element.name: SetDateTime
element.short: Set the current system date and time

descr.p: SetDate sets the system date and time to year, month, day, hour, min, Sec. This is the kernel date/time, so it is in GMT. The time is not touched. The function returns True if the call was executed corretly, False otherwise.
descr.remark: You must be root to execute this call.

descr.p: ExitProcess exits the currently running process, and report Val as the exit status.
descr.remark: If this call is executed, the normal unit finalization code will not be executed. This may lead to unexpected errors and stray files on your system. It is therefore recommended to use the Halt call instead.

descr.p: WaitProcess waits for process PID to exit. WaitProcess is equivalent to the call:
Handles of Signal interrupts (errno=EINTR), and returns the Exitcode of Process PID (>=0) or -Status if it was terminated

element.name: WEXITSTATUS
element.short: Extract the exit status from the result.
element.descr: WEXITSTATUS can be used to extract the exit status from Status, the result of the call.

element.name: WTERMSIG
element.short: Return the signal that caused a process to exit.
element.descr: WTERMSIG extracts from Status the signal number which caused the process to exit.

element.name: WSTOPSIG
element.short: Return the exit code from the process.
element.descr: WSTOPSIG is an alias for .

element.name: WIFEXITED
element.short: Check whether the process exited normally
element.descr: WIFEXITED checks Status and returns True if the status indicates that the process terminated normally, i.e. was not stopped by a signal.

element.name: WIFSTOPPED
element.short: Check whether the process is currently stopped.
element.descr: WIFSTOPPED checks Status and returns true if the process is currently stopped. This is only possible if WUNTRACED was specified in the options of .

element.name: WIFSIGNALED
element.short: Check whether the process was exited by a signal.
element.descr: WIFSIGNALED returns True if Status indicates that the process exited because it received a signal.

element.name: W_EXITCODE
element.short: Construct an exit status based on an return code and signal.
element.descr: W_EXITCODE combines ReturnCode and Signal to a status code fit for WaitPid.

element.name: W_STOPCODE
element.short: Construct an exit status based on a signal.
element.descr: W_STOPCODE constructs an exit status based on Signal, which will cause to return True

element.name: MAP_GROWSDOWN
element.short: option: Memory grows downward (like a stack)

element.name: MAP_LOCKED
element.short: option: lock the pages in memory.

element.name: MAP_NORESERVE
element.short: option: Do not reserve swap pages for this memory.

element.name: IoPL
element.descr: IoPL sets the I/O privilige level. It is intended for completeness only, one should normally not use it.
